intro: Malvaviscus palmeri, commonly known as the desert mallow, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It belongs to the Malvaceae family, which includes hibiscus and cotton, and is characterized by its showy, trumpet-shaped flowers. The plant has hairy, succulent stems and leaves that are often lobed, adapted to thrive in arid environments. Its flowers, which range in color from white to pink, are pollinated primarily by bees and other insects. Malvaviscus palmeri is often found in rocky soils and can withstand drought conditions due to its deep root system.
